A few years back, there were some urban freerange chickens in the middle of Yuba City, California. Their free range generally was the side of State Highway 99. One day a very excited man hurried into the police station and told the desk officer that he needed help as he had a chicken stuck between his wiper and the windshield.

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Charlottesville's ordinance is below. It's permissive, banning only free range fowl and at large livestock, as well as animal cruelty. We don't regulate the number of fowl or the type of enclosure, as some ordinances do. We do regulate goats more carefully. I think that specifying lot size or separation is asking for trouble --better to use your general and pre-existing cruelty and nuisance rules to address any problems which arise (you might need to check your mowed-grass rules). We tend to encourage our urban farmers' creativity. Hens and square-foot gardening techniques can be fit into remarkably small spaces: I have a neighbor with a basement apartment and a walk-out garden with five happy hens and splendid tomatoes on not more than 400 fenced square feet.
Pro: encourage local food movement, sustainability, and food awareness.
Con: Risk of noise and nuisance complaints. I don't know of any significant escapes or cruelty problems here. 
http://library.municode.com/HTML/12078/level3/CO_CH4ANFO_ARTIINGE.html#TOPTITLE
Lastly, this story of a neighbor of mine, offering social services and urban farming on a small lot. Their chickens and goats are pretty adorable. http://www.c-ville.com/local-catholic-couple-runs-casa-alma-a-refuge-for-those-in-need/#.UQBSNB3pet8

answers.author: Jennifer Smith
answers.text:
The below information is actually from my colleague, Kim Haun (khaun@arlingtonva.us), who works in our Parks and Recreation Department. (P.S. Also we also posted a question on this topic in our OpenArington forum, operated by Peak Democracy -- openarlington.us -- 47 responses thus far.
The Arlington County Urban Agriculture Initiative Citizen Task Force is researching this very question.  We have reviewed literature from many jurisdictions across the country and in Europe.  We have also spoken with public health, animal welfare, and animal husbandry experts in addition to public advocacy groups pro and con.  We have not yet reached a consensus on a recommendation for whether to loosen the current restrictions on poultry (or other small livestock) in Arlington, but some of the factors were are examining include:

Hen registration fee and permit
Pre-approval of coop and run plan and location
Inspection of same prior to permitting
Permission of all neighbors required
Limit number of hens, prohibit roosters
Require minimum distance (TBD) from property lines
Education program on henkeeping -- required or optional
Test program with a limited pilot

Will protocols such as the above, if enforced properly, eliminate or minimize public health, rodents, noise, odor, predators and other considerations?  How will the program be monitored and what is the enforcement scheme.  How much will all this cost?  It is worth it?
The current code in Arlington actually does not prohibit small livestock per se, but the setback restrictions effectively do so.  I think at last count only 11 private properties were large enough.  I do not think any of these actually have livestock.
Our recommendations are due to the CBO in April.
Let me know if I can provide any further information!
